text: Happy Friday, everybody. It's the 5th of July. And I want to talk through the expiration cycle for today. A lot of options came off. We can see a lot went back out over 200 and 39,000 calls transacted today, which is a heavy number compared to what we saw back on the 3rd of June, which it was actually starting to slow down for a couple days. And we definitely accelerated back up today being over 200,000 calls again. We did see puts also expand. We have 75,000 puts traded today. Heavy, heavy, heavy callsque. No doubt about it in terms of transactions. Now, if we take a look at where the majority of these transactions occurred and calls notice 37 of the transaction today were at the bid or below. These are sales. These are people selling calls. Then the 29, those are people buying calls. If we look on the put side, most people came in slight edge by one point over the bid where 32 came in at the offer, those people buying puts. So this is expectation of downside by a very slight edge. And then this is not necessarily expectation of downside. This can be covered calls, but that still would benefit from a slight down move on the options perspective. Obviously, if you sell a covered call, you still want the underlying to go up. That's where Max profit in the trade lies. So let's take a look at what's going on here,

Now, if we go into this expiration of the five July, we're going to lose almost 200,000 calls. They're going to expire. They're going to be gone. And then on the put side, we're going to lose 84,000. So what's going to happen here is this essentially 900,000 calls is going to drop almost by 200K. So there's still going to be really heavy call, oh, I skew. But we're starting to move out obviously into the next cycles, 12 July, which I know right now has been sent into me a few times that that's apparently an expiration cycle to look out for based on the T 35 cycle. The very first thing is we need to pay pretty close attention to where we're starting to see volume flowing in. So we can see that there's a lot of volume today. This is probably people trying to get out of positions and collect a few pennies to save what money they can. Notice all these blue dots. Those are for today's expiration. So if we kill that and we look at the next series of interesting expressions, now the blue dots are 12 July and that's kind of people are just moving out one week. That's what we're seeing. Everybody's trying to maintain as much sensitivity to the front expiration cycle because that's where the perception is of these really big moves happening, which right now it's generally quiet. Inplied volatility is high, but it's low on a relative basis. So what that means is if we take a look up here and we take a look at the IV by itself, it's at 127. The IV rank is all the way down at 23 and then the IV percentile is up at 73. If you're unfamiliar with IV rank versus percentile, IV percentile is less prone to skew whereas IV rank is very prone to skew. That's actually why IV rank looks so low compared to IV percentile. text: then the IV percentile is up at 73. If you're unfamiliar with IV rank versus percentile, IV percentile is less prone to skew whereas IV rank is very prone to skew. That's actually why IV rank looks so low compared to IV percentile. But for something like GameStop, implied volatility can fly off the handle any second. So even though IV percentile is still showing elevated here, I think it's because if we look back over the past year, it had such periods of supremely depressed volatility. So I actually think a better metric is to kind of use from like the third of May forward and project your volatility out of this, which would be a little bit more representative of kind of this near term paradigm that we're in with respect to volatility for GameStop. So when I look at this, I'm not seeing anything jumping out at me in terms of huge positions being built. I'm seeing lighter volume for these at the monies out in 16 August.
